title: CVPR_2011_10_abs

sentences.text: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other .
This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition .
This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points .
It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other .
We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors .
We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

Entity-this_work.label: This work
Entity-this_work.description: This work refers to a research study that introduces an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing the motion trajectories of feature points, addressing the challenges posed by multiple overlapping layers in image processing.

Entity-reflection_in_image_sequence.label: Reflections in image sequences
Entity-reflection_in_image_sequence.description: Reflections in image sequences refer to a visual phenomenon where multiple layers of images overlap, complicating image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition due to the presence of two distinct moving layers.

Entity-reflection.label: reflections
Entity-reflection.description: Reflections refer to the optical phenomenon in image sequences where multiple layers of images are superimposed, complicating image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition.

Entity-automated_technique.label: automated technique
Entity-automated_technique.description: The automated technique refers to a method for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing the motion trajectories of feature points, effectively modeling reflections as overlapping layers of motion.

Entity-detector.label: detector
Entity-detector.description: The 'detector' refers to a robust algorithm designed to identify reflections in image sequences by integrating multiple weak detection methods to enhance accuracy and performance.

Entity-region.label: regions
Entity-region.description: In the context of image processing, 'regions' refers to areas within an image sequence that contain two superimposed layers, which are analyzed to detect reflections caused by their movement.

Entity-a_set_of_weak_detector.label: a set of weak detectors
Entity-a_set_of_weak_detector.description: A set of weak detectors refers to multiple individual detection algorithms or methods that, when combined, enhance the overall performance of detecting reflections in image sequences, particularly in challenging scenarios involving overlapping layers of motion.

Entity-two_different_layer.label: two different layers
Entity-two_different_layer.description: The term 'two different layers' refers to the distinct superimposed layers in image sequences that represent reflections, which move independently and complicate image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition.

Entity-high_detection_rate.label: high detection rate
Entity-high_detection_rate.description: The term 'high detection rate' refers to the effectiveness of the proposed automated technique in accurately identifying reflections in image sequences, demonstrating superior performance in distinguishing these reflections despite challenges such as pathological motion and occlusion.

Entity-region_containing_two_different_l.label: regions containing two different layers
Entity-region_containing_two_different_l.description: The term 'regions containing two different layers' refers to areas in image sequences where multiple layers of reflections overlap and move, complicating image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition.

Entity-sparse_and_dense_detection_map.label: sparse and dense detection maps
Entity-sparse_and_dense_detection_map.description: Sparse and dense detection maps refer to the output representations generated by the proposed automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences, which utilize both sparse and dense sampling of feature points to enhance detection accuracy in the presence of complex motion and occlusions.

Entity-strong_detector.label: strong detector
Entity-strong_detector.description: The 'strong detector' refers to an advanced detection mechanism that integrates multiple weak detectors to effectively identify reflections in image sequences, enhancing detection rates while managing challenges such as pathological motion and occlusion.

Entity-moving_over_each_other.label: moving over each other
Entity-moving_over_each_other.description: The term 'moving over each other' refers to the interaction of two distinct layers in image sequences, specifically in the context of reflections, where these layers exhibit relative motion, complicating image processing tasks.

Entity-motion_trajectory_of_feature_poin.label: motion trajectories of feature points
Entity-motion_trajectory_of_feature_poin.description: Motion trajectories of feature points refer to the paths traced by distinct points of interest in an image sequence, which are analyzed to detect and differentiate overlapping layers caused by reflections in the visual data.

Entity-layer.label: layers
Entity-layer.description: In the context of image processing, 'layers' refer to the multiple superimposed regions in reflections within image sequences that complicate analysis by creating overlapping visual information.

Entity-weak_detector.label: weak detectors
Entity-weak_detector.description: Weak detectors refer to individual detection algorithms or components that, when combined, enhance the overall performance of a stronger detection system for identifying reflections in image sequences.

Entity-pathological_motion.label: pathological motion
Entity-pathological_motion.description: Pathological motion refers to complex or problematic motion patterns in image sequences that can interfere with image processing techniques, particularly in the context of detecting reflections caused by overlapping layers.

Entity-occlusion.label: occlusion
Entity-occlusion.description: In the context of image processing and computer vision, 'occlusion' refers to the visual phenomenon where one object obstructs the view of another, complicating tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition due to the presence of multiple overlapping layers in image sequences.

Entity-novel_prior.label: novel priors
Entity-novel_prior.description: Novel priors refer to innovative assumptions or statistical models employed in the context of image processing to enhance the detection of reflections in image sequences by effectively managing the complexities of layered motion.

Entity-motion_estimation.label: motion estimation
Entity-motion_estimation.description: Motion estimation is a computational technique used in image processing to determine the motion of objects between consecutive frames in a video sequence.

Entity-image_sequence.label: image sequences
Entity-image_sequence.description: Image sequences are a series of images arranged in a specific order, often used to represent motion or changes over time in visual data.

Entity-feature_point.label: feature points
Entity-feature_point.description: Feature points are distinct and identifiable locations in an image that are used for various image processing tasks, such as object recognition and tracking.

Entity-object_recognition.label: object recognition
Entity-object_recognition.description: Object recognition is a computer vision technique that enables the identification and classification of objects within digital images or video streams.

Entity-detection_rate.label: detection rate
Entity-detection_rate.description: Detection rate is a performance metric that quantifies the proportion of actual positive instances that are correctly identified by a detection system.

Entity-motion_trajectory.label: motion trajectories
Entity-motion_trajectory.description: Motion trajectories refer to the paths or patterns that moving objects follow over time, often represented in a spatial context for analysis in fields such as motion analysis and spatial analysis.

Entity-image_processing_technique.label: image processing techniques
Entity-image_processing_technique.description: Image processing techniques are methodologies used to manipulate and analyze digital images to enhance their quality or extract useful information.

summary: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other . This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition . This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points . It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other . We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors . We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

Predicate-consist_of.label: consist of
Predicate-consist_of.description: The predicate 'consist of' indicates that the subject is made up of or composed of the elements represented by the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is seen as a whole that is formed from various parts or components, which are specified by the object.

Predicate-causes.label: causes
Predicate-causes.description: The predicate 'causes' indicates a relationship where the subject brings about, influences, or leads to a change or effect represented by the object. It implies a causal connection where the occurrence or existence of the subject results in the manifestation or development of the object.

Predicate-fail_as_they_assume_the_presen.label: fail as they assume the presence of
Predicate-fail_as_they_assume_the_presen.description: The predicate 'fail as they assume the presence of' indicates that the subject does not succeed or is ineffective due to an incorrect or unverified assumption regarding the existence or influence of the object. This suggests a causal relationship where the failure of the subject is directly linked to the presumption that the object is present or relevant in a given context.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or making known the object to an audience. It implies a formal or structured communication of information, findings, or concepts, where the subject serves as the source or origin of the presentation, and the object represents the content or subject matter being conveyed.

Predicate-detects.label: detects
Predicate-detects.description: The predicate 'detects' indicates the action of identifying or discovering the presence of a particular phenomenon, feature, or element within a given context. It establishes a relationship where the subject is capable of recognizing or perceiving the object, which represents the specific entity or occurrence being identified. This action often involves the use of methods, tools, or processes that enable the subject to observe or analyze the object effectively.

Predicate-analyzes.label: analyzes
Predicate-analyzes.description: The predicate 'analyzes' denotes an action where the subject systematically examines, inspects, or studies the object in order to understand its structure, characteristics, or underlying patterns. This process often involves breaking down the object into its components or aspects to derive insights, make interpretations, or draw conclusions based on the information contained within the object.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates that the subject encompasses or holds within it the object, suggesting a relationship where the object is an integral part or component of the subject. This relationship implies that the subject has the capacity to include or comprise the object, which can be a physical entity, concept, or any defined element.

Predicate-models.label: models
Predicate-models.description: The predicate 'models' indicates a relationship where the subject serves as a representation or example of the object, illustrating or simulating its characteristics, behaviors, or properties. In this context, the subject provides a framework or structure that encapsulates the essence of the object, allowing for analysis, understanding, or visualization of the object's attributes.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' serves as a linking verb that connects the subject to the object by indicating a state of being or existence. It establishes a relationship where the subject is characterized or defined by the object, often implying an ongoing action or condition that the subject is experiencing or exhibiting.

Predicate-models_as.label: models as
Predicate-models_as.description: The predicate 'models as' establishes a relationship where the subject is represented or conceptualized in a manner that aligns with the characteristics or properties of the object. It indicates that the subject serves as a representation or example of the object, suggesting a similarity or analogy between the two.

Predicate-is_based_on_combining.label: is based on combining
Predicate-is_based_on_combining.description: The predicate 'is based on combining' indicates that the subject derives its functionality, effectiveness, or characteristics from the integration or synthesis of multiple components or elements represented by the object. This suggests a foundational relationship where the subject's capabilities are enhanced or established through the amalgamation of the specified components.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates that the subject is founded upon, derived from, or relies upon the object as a fundamental component, principle, or source of support. It establishes a relationship where the subject's characteristics, functionality, or validity are contingent upon the object.

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: The predicate 'generate' indicates the action of producing or creating something as a result of a process or set of conditions. In the context of the subject and object, it signifies that the subject is responsible for the creation of the object, which can be a tangible or intangible entity. This relationship highlights the transformative effect of the subject on the object, where the subject's characteristics or actions lead to the emergence of the object.

Predicate-with_rejection_to.label: with rejection to
Predicate-with_rejection_to.description: The predicate 'with rejection to' indicates a relationship where the subject is being evaluated or considered in relation to the object, often implying a focus on excluding or disregarding the object in the context of the subject's characteristics or performance. It suggests that the subject's qualities or outcomes are assessed while specifically not taking the object into account.

Predicate-introduces_an_automated_techni.label: introduces an automated technique for detecting
Predicate-introduces_an_automated_techni.description: The predicate 'introduces an automated technique for detecting' signifies the act of presenting or proposing a systematic method that utilizes automation to identify or recognize specific phenomena or patterns within a given context. In this structure, the subject is the entity that is presenting the technique, while the object represents the particular aspect or phenomenon that the technique is designed to identify. This connection highlights the innovation and application of technology in enhancing detection processes.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or concept that falls under the wider category or concept represented by the object. This relationship is often used in classification systems, taxonomies, or ontologies to show how different terms relate to each other in terms of specificity and generality.
